title: How to Cook Rice in a Pure Clay Pot

steps.headline: Wet the pot on the inside and add the desired amount of rice/grains.
steps.description: If cooking rice, wash it 1-2 times, if it's quinoa, wash it one time. Then add the necessary amount of water to the pot. For example, if it’s long grain Basmati rice, add 4 cups of water to 2 cups of rice, if it’s parboiled rice, add 3 cups of water to every one cup of rice. If cooking quinoa, add 2 cups of water to 1 cups of quinoa.

steps.headline: Set the pot with the grains and water mixture on the stove top.
steps.description: If you like to cook your grains with salt, you can add a pinch of sea salt at this time, stir it in and cover the pot with its lid. If cooking on an electric stove top, use a diffuser between the pot and the elements to spread the heat evenly. If cooking on a gas top there is no need for a diffuser.

steps.headline: Start the stove on low, anywhere between 1 to 3 on a scale of 1 to 10.
steps.description: Let it stay at that heat for 5 minutes, then increase to a medium heat.

steps.headline: Let the rice cook at the medium setting.
steps.description:
When the time is almost up, check to see if the rice is almost cooked – only a little water should be left in the pot, and the rice will look almost done. Cook the rice for the following amount of time:
3-4 cups of rice: 20 minutes
5-6 cups of rice: 30-35 minutes
More than 6 cups of rice: 40-45 minutes

steps.headline: Turn the stove off.
steps.description: Let the pot sit on the stove and let the grains finish cooking with the heat locked inside the pot. Pure-clay pots retain all the heat given to them inside the pot so food can finish cooking with just this heat, without the need for additional heat from the stove.

steps.headline: Open the lid.
steps.description: Your fluffy, soft delicious rice is ready!

steps.headline: Insert a wooden spoon and gently scrape the bottom.
steps.description: This will reveal that no food is stuck to the bottom.

text:
Wet the pot on the inside and add the desired amount of rice/grains. If cooking rice, wash it 1-2 times, if it's quinoa, wash it one time. Then add the necessary amount of water to the pot. For example, if it’s long grain Basmati rice, add 4 cups of water to 2 cups of rice, if it’s parboiled rice, add 3 cups of water to every one cup of rice. If cooking quinoa, add 2 cups of water to 1 cups of quinoa. Set the pot with the grains and water mixture on the stove top. If you like to cook your grains with salt, you can add a pinch of sea salt at this time, stir it in and cover the pot with its lid. If cooking on an electric stove top, use a diffuser between the pot and the elements to spread the heat evenly. If cooking on a gas top there is no need for a diffuser. Start the stove on low, anywhere between 1 to 3 on a scale of 1 to 10. Let it stay at that heat for 5 minutes, then increase to a medium heat. Let the rice cook at the medium setting. When the time is almost up, check to see if the rice is almost cooked – only a little water should be left in the pot, and the rice will look almost done. Cook the rice for the following amount of time:
3-4 cups of rice: 20 minutes
5-6 cups of rice: 30-35 minutes
More than 6 cups of rice: 40-45 minutes Turn the stove off. Let the pot sit on the stove and let the grains finish cooking with the heat locked inside the pot. Pure-clay pots retain all the heat given to them inside the pot so food can finish cooking with just this heat, without the need for additional heat from the stove. Open the lid. Your fluffy, soft delicious rice is ready! Insert a wooden spoon and gently scrape the bottom. This will reveal that no food is stuck to the bottom.
